awd_titl_txt: Interactive STEM Education Competence in Teaching
awd_abstract_narration:
Mathematics and science concepts and skills acquired in elementary school form the foundation for future success in STEM fields and yet students in eastern North Carolina and across the nation struggle to demonstrate proficiency on state and national tests.  This project seeks to address one area affecting student outcomes, the nature and role of discipline-specific discourse and argumentation.  The goal of the project is an empirical exploration of immersive classroom simulation activities (ICSAs) on pre-service mathematics and science teachers' competence and confidence in discourse use.  Student-to-student and student-to-teacher discourse are critical components of standards-based practices shown to improve learning outcomes and are also foundational tenets of mathematical and scientific pedagogical practices in standards documents.  Teachers promote explanation and justification, critical for students to develop understanding, through questioning.  Discourse is a key factor in making content meaningful and relevant for learners, an important construct for engagement, short- and long-term learning outcomes, and persistence.  Traditional teaching simulation activities such as peer-to-peer role-play are limited, brief, and challenging to replicate to provide sufficient practice for discourse skill development. Virtual simulation provides immersive, interactive learning and gives candidates an opportunity to practice complex skills, which cannot be replicated with typical fieldwork, and thus, enables practice-based teacher development. 

This longitudinal, mixed methods study will measure the impact in methods courses, practica, and internship placements of the use of ICSAs on facility with discourse skills to promote learning and engagement of all students in mathematics and science. The sample sizes of 120 achieve 80% power to reject the null hypothesis of equal means when the population mean difference is 8.1 with standard deviations of 15.8, and with a significance level (alpha) of 0.050 using a two-sided two-sample t-test where the variances are not assumed equal. The Analyzing Teacher Moves (ATM) instrument will be used to examine discourse practices speech acts using (Correnti, et al., 2015). ATM outcomes will be determined with the Weighted-Discussion-Scoring (WDS) guide (Scherrer, 2013) and the Weighted-Positive-Scoring (WPS) adapted by Lee (2016). Along with the opportunity to develop teacher practice without placing "real students" at risk during the learning process, another benefit of ICSAs is improved access to teacher learning-in-action for analytical purposes. The project adds to a growing pool of research leveraging digital media to improve design for learning and develops a framework to better prepare pre-service researchers to develop and use discourse in their college classrooms.  This project responds to the National Science Foundation's Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) request for proposals addressing "immediate challenges and opportunities facing undergraduate STEM education," as it relates to the preparation of teachers of STEM disciplinary content and practices.  Should ICSAs prove effective, this project will provide ICSA scenarios, guidelines, and approaches to teacher preparation programs across the country.  This important work is supported with funding from the IUSE program and the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program.

por.por_cntn:
An interdisciplinary team of researchers from East Carolina University’s College of Education and College of Engineering and Technology were funded in 2017 by a three-year, $599,939 grant through the Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) program. This project focuses on the development of discourse on math and science topics between teacher candidates and students using a virtual rehearsal simulation (VRS) (Mursion) to practice math and science methods with student avatars. This project follows cohorts of students through mathematics methods courses or science methods courses, and into their internship in schools. The goal of the project is to determine if the integration of VRS in math and science education courses improves teacher candidates’ ability to communicate and to facilitate discussion on math and science topics. Teacher candidates exposed to the VRS are compared to a control group of teacher candidates who practice math or science methods through peer roleplaying.  This project also explored how the development of these discourse skills impacted teacher candidates’ capacity to engage with more diverse student populations. Our studies within the mathematics methods courses involved 192 teacher candidates. A subset of 33 teacher candidates submitted videos in their senior internship and their discourse skills were analyzed. There was a total of 95 participants involved in the science methods courses of the study. A total of 262 science talks were recorded, transcribed, and analyzed. Both the math and science researchers utilized a similar codebook, Analyzing Teacher Moves, for coding all science and math talks. Adaptations were made to the codebook for a more nuance understanding of the differences of discourse in math and science discussions.  Project INTERSECT provides empirical evidence in support of the assertion that it is not only possible for Virtual Rehearsal Simulation (VRS) to similarly support elicitation skill development as compared to more traditional peer-to-peer rehearsal contexts, but it can enhance teacher candidates’ facilitation of mathematical and science discussions in authentic elementary classrooms settings. Participants that used the VRS context increased in their use of discourse skills that promoted student thinking by responding to student avatars’ ideas by asking more opened ended questions, promoting student engagement with avatars, and comparing the experience to being “realistic” to a classroom setting.  Participants using the VRS environment were able to transfer more student-centered discourse moves such as Pushback in the classroom setting of the practicum for science.  This result is encouraging since the Pushback move is a more complex pedagogical skill of discourse that requires teacher candidates to analyze the students’ thinking but then challenge the student to defend or explain on their ideas during the discussion. In the VRS context, the teacher candidates focused more on how to respond to and manage the avatar students’ mathematical thinking while in the peer-to-peer rehearsals teacher candidates often dived into their own understanding of the mathematics. Also, the role of the interactor in the VRS was key in providing learning opportunities that were not available from peers. When in their senior internships, TCs increased their use of prompts for explanation in their classroom enactments if they rehearsed with VRS as a compared to peer-to-peer.  On average, TCs who practiced with VRS utilized significantly more funds of knowledge talk moves per minute than those who practiced with Peer to Peer. This provides evidence that VRS (Mursion) may be a more supportive model for teacher candidates to practice discourse moves that engage students’ knowledge from outside the classroom experiences. Helping teacher candidates to value and utilize the various “funds of knowledge” their students learn at home offers a promising strategy to further support teacher candidates’ culturally responsive pedagogy. On average, TCs in the Mursion-based lesson group utilized a significantly greater number of ‘Confirmation’ and ‘Pushback’ Funds of Knowledge Teacher Moves (FOKTMs) per minute than teacher candidates’ in the peer-based lesson group. Conversely, teacher candidates in the peer-based lesson group utilized a significantly greater number of ‘Repeat’ FOKTMs per minute than TCs in the Mursion group. This provides evidence that Mursion may challenge teacher candidates to use more sophisticated funds of knowledge discourse moves while engaging in meaning making with students. Study results have shown that it is possible for VRS to similarly support student elicitation skill development and authentic teaching context implementation as compared to more traditional peer-to-peer rehearsal  contexts. Implications are that teacher preparation programs have empirical evidence to support the use of an alternative, technology-based instructional tool in their programs. We also found that particular actor choices in portrayals provide confirmatory support for implicit biases and negatively impact student learning among teacher candidates who identify as being of the same race as avatars that they feel are not portrayed in an authentic way. Implications for actor training exist and should be explored in future projects.
